abstracts.cdata!:
The Demobilization and Reintegration
            Program Project for Eritrea had a moderately satisfactory
            outcome and a substantial risk to development outcome. Both
            the Bank and the borrower performances were moderately
            satisfactory. The main lessons learned include: (1)
            Political economy challenges reduced the effectiveness of
            the project. The shift in political situation in the country
            prevailing for most of the project implementation did not
            allow the Government of Eritrea to demobilize all the
            200,000 soldiers as envisaged, leading to the adjustments in
            the project which were made during the MTR in 2005 to
            partially reflect the new situation. (2) Unrealized funding
            pledges can affect project implementation and results. (3)
            Project management effectiveness is enhanced by support
            arising from highest level of the Government. The high level
            support enabled the NCDRP to mobilize other actors in the
            country behind common policy goals. (4) Timely reinsertion
            payments effectively delivered immediate benefits to the
            demobilized soldiers (DS). (5) The social reintegration
            process holds the key for the overall DS reintegration
            process. (6) Targeting reintegration support to the DS in
            combination with support to the wider community with a
            gradual shift towards the latter lead to effective
            achievement of results. (7) Importance of using the
            institutional structures in place.
